Dear Ms. Brewer:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 11/09/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(d) Work history.
Three out of 11 employee files reviewed did not contain the proper work history
for that individual.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained
prior to employment from persons unrelated

to the employee and which are less than 12
months old.
Four out of 11 employee files reviewed did not contain the three dated unrelated
references prior to employment.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(g) If the employee has criminal convictions, the
institution shall complete a written evaluation
of the convictions that addresses the nature
of the conviction, the length of time since the
conviction, and the relationship of the
conviction to regulated activity for the
purpose of determining suitability for
employment in the institution.
One out of 11 employee files reviewed did not contain an assessment dated prior
to hire from the facility on the individual's criminal convictions.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(h) A statement from the employee regarding
any convictions.
One out of 11 employee files reviewed did not contain an assessment dated prior
to hire from the individual addressing past criminal convictions.
CCI Rule 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and
volunteers
(1) The licensee shall document, prior to
employment, that each employee and volunteer
who has contact with residents 4 or more hours
per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is
free from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom
from communicable tuberculosis shall be
verified within the 1 year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year

after the last verification or prior to the
expiration of the current verification.
One out of 11 employee files reviewed did not contain a negative Tuberculosis
test dated prior to hire.
CCI Rule 400.4123 Education
(2) Provision shall be made for an appropriate
education program in accordance with 1976 PA
451, MCL 380.1 to 380.1853. Each resident of
school age shall be enrolled not later than 5
school days after admission and continuously
thereafter.
Two out of three youth files reviewed did not contain adequate documentation
showing that the youth had been enrolled in school within five days of moving in
to the program.
CCI Rule 400.4144 Admission health screening; physical
examinations.
(1) An initial health screening shall be completed
for each resident within 24 hours of admission
to a facility.
One out of three youth files reviewed did not contain a health screening
performed by staff within 24 hours of admission to the program.
CCI Rule 400.4144 Admission health screening; physical
examinations.
(3) Sufficient health history information shall be
documented for each resident to assure proper
medical care.
Two out of three youth files reviewed did not contain adequate health history for
the youth gathered at the time of intake.
CCI Rule 400.4150 Incident reporting
(1) Any incident resulting in serious injury of a
resident or illness requiring inpatient
hospitalization, shall be reported to the parent/
legal guardian, responsible referring agency,
and the licensing authority as soon as possible,
but not more than 24 hours after the incident.

Two out of three youth files reviewed did not contain incident report
documentation for a youth's contact with a hospital setting.
CCI Rule 400.4152 Initial documentation
(1) At the time of admission, all of the following
shall be in the resident’s case record:
(c) A brief description of the resident’s
preparation for placement and general
physical and emotional state at the time of
admission.
Three out of three youth files reviewed did not contain a brief description of the
resident's preparation for placement in the program at the time of admission.
CCI Rule 400.4152 Initial documentation
(1) At the time of admission, all of the following
shall be in the resident’s case record:
(d) Name, address, and marital status of parents
and name and address of legal guardian, if
known.
Two out of three youth files reviewed did not contain the full information required
for the parents or legal guardian of a youth.
CCI Rule 400.4152 Initial documentation
(1) At the time of admission, all of the following
shall be in the resident’s case record:
(e) Date of admission and legal status.
One out of three youth files reviewed did not contain the required legal
information for youth placed in the program.
CCI Rule 400.4152 Initial documentation
(1) At the time of admission, all of the following
shall be in the resident’s case record:
(g) Authorization to provide medical, dental, and
surgical care and treatment as provided in
section 14 a (1), (2), and (3) of 1973 PA 116,
MCL 722.124a.
One out of three youth files reviewed did not contain an authorization for the
facility to seek medical care for the youth.
CCI Rule 400.4152 Initial documentation

(1) At the time of admission, all of the following
shall be in the resident’s case record:
(h) A brief description of the circumstances
leading to the need for care.
Two out of three youth files reviewed did not contain a brief description of the
circumstances leading to care for the youth.
CCI Rule 400.4152 Initial documentation
(1) At the time of admission, all of the following
shall be in the resident’s case record:
(i) Documentation that the grievance policy was
provided as required in R 400.4132.
Three out of three youth files reviewed did not contain documentation that the
facility's grievance policy was provided as required.
CCI Rule 400.4153 Shelter care and detention institutions; preliminary
service plans
(1) Within 7 calendar days of admission, a plan
shall be developed for each resident. The plan
shall include all of the following:
(a) The reason for care.
(b) An assessment of the resident’s immediate
and specific needs
(c) The specific services to be provided by the
institution.
(d) Other resources to meet the resident’s
needs.
Two out of three youth files reviewed did not contain a complete preliminary
service plan dated within seven days of the placement.
CCI Rule 400.4154 Shelter care and detention institutions; service
plans.
(1) Within 30 calendar days after admission and
every 15 calendar days thereafter, an institution
shall complete a written service plan. The
service plan shall include all of the following:
(a) The reason for continued care.
(b) Evaluation of service needs.
(c) Ongoing service needs.
(d) How service needs will be met.
(e) Unmet service needs and the reasons those
needs are unmet.

One out of one applicable youth files reviewed did not contain updated service
planning.
CCI Rule 400.4154 Shelter care and detention institutions; service
plans.
(2) Copies of the plan shall be maintained at the
institution.
One out of three youth files reviewed did not contain copies of updated service
planning maintained at the institution.
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days
after discharge:
(a) The date of and reason for discharge, and the
new location of the child.
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of
the services provided while in residence,
including medical and dental services.
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that
remain to be met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the
facility after discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and
dental follow up that is needed, have been
reviewed with the resident and with the
parent and with the responsible case
manager.
(f) The name and official title of the person to
whom the resident was discharged.
Two out of two discharged youth files reviewed did not contain complete
dfischarge planning.
CCI Rule 400.4167 Case record maintenance
(2) Service plans shall be signed and dated by the
social services worker and the social services
supervisor.
Two out of two discharged youth files reviewed did not contain service plans that
were signed and dated by the social service worker and their supervisor.
CCI Rule 400.4167 Case record maintenance

4) Records shall be maintained in a uniform and
organized manner, shall be protected against
destruction and damage, and shall be stored in
a manner that safeguards confidentiality.
At the time of inspection the facility did not have youth case files stored in a
manner that safeguarded confidentiality, nor did they have case files completed in
an organized manner.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Consistency is needed in the use of standardized intake and service plans forms
in order to guarantee that required information by the licensing rules is
documented.
• Clear documentation can be designed to show that a youth was provided certain
information at the time of intake, such as the provision of the facilities grievance
policy. This could include a signature from the youth to document that receipt of
information.
• Communication with other shelter programs, contracted and non-contracted,
would be of significant benefit to learn more ideas and strategies for care of the
youth, documentation efforts, and how to work collaboratively with community
partners.
• There is concern that the behavior management programming contains
unrealistic expectations for the youth the program seeks to serve. Further
exploration of how to best meet the youth’s needs with a trauma informed and
realistic approach while maintaining safety within the program is required to
continue to improve.
• Further understanding of the requirements within the CCI rules is necessary to
ensure compliance going forward.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Any pictures of youth should be dated.
• The facility should use available information systems to attempt to gather
required information for youth at the time of intake.
• The facility should ensure that narratives from past documentation is not copy
and pasted on to new documentation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance

The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
facility has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan during this licensing
period as a result of a Licensing special investigations, and compliance with that
CAP is as as follows: The CAP addressed facility policy on behavior management
because of an escalated incident that involved a staff member restraining a youth
when the facility is not approved for nor trained in a proper restraint protocol.
Training and review of behavior management efforts in monthly staff meetings was
proposed. Ongoing CAP monitoring is conducted with the facility, and they are
complying with the CAP at this time.
Financial Overview
This inspection period does not cover the first full year of operations of this
program so a full financial analysis was not able to be provided. Information
covering the program's current budget and expenses was provided. There is
concern over the facilities long term financial health but there are adequate funds
and contracted income to assure that proper care of youth is provided at this time.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
Because this inspection period is within the first year of the facilities operations, no
yearly Chief Administrator report has been completed. The facility is aware of this
requirement heading into next year.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff were interviewed during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility on
10/26/2023 and an announced, face-to-face visit at the facility on 11/09/2023.
Staff reported they have enjoyed working with the youth in the new program,
despite difficulties with youth's behaviors.
Youth were interviewed during an announced, face-to-face visit at the facility on
11/09/2023. Several youth voiced displeasure with house rules and staff
consistency. Youth described escalated incidents that involved staff not appearing
to be competent in de-escalation or intervention with the youth. Youth also
described concerns with food at the facility but were clear in that there are not
concerns about food safety. Youth also described a lack of knowledge and
consistency in their daily schedule at the house outside of school hours, as well as
the provision of mental health services and group work.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The facility was toured during an announced, face-to-face visit at the facility on
11/09/2023. The home was clean and organized. Youth bedrooms were viewed,
and no safety concerns were present. The kitchen was viewed as well and there

were sufficient groceries for youth and all cleaning items were stored in an
appropriate manner.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
